MSJC Board Awards Interim Superintendent Jon Tyler’s Contract by new agenda item on “pink sheet posting”

Monday, June 18th, 2007

http://www.brownact.org/ The vote on the contract was 4-1 (Motte opposed).

“Pink Sheets” at MSJC are pink colored paper sheets used for revisions and/or corrections for existing board posted agenda items. Note: key word “existing”.

“Pink Sheets” are distributed when necessary, before the start of a board meeting and recognized by the chair at a point on the agenda as “additions/deletions”.

Scenario:

At the June 14, 2007 BOT meeting, Board Chair, Eugene Kadow, called the meeting to order and followed the agenda as posted. Under item 1.6 on the agenda he distributed one “pink sheet” as a REVISED EXHIBIT for Item 2006-07/189.

After completion of items 1.1 through 2.0 of the agenda, Kadow requested the board to convene to closed session to consider Item 8.5 on the Closed Session Agenda. (Conference With Labor Negotiator - Unrepresented employees Administration/Supervisory/Confidential)

The board left open session to meet in closed session, then reconvened to open session with no reported action taken from closed session.

Before consideration of the Consent Agenda, a new “pink sheet” was distributed to the board by the Chair, marked “REVISED EXHIBIT” for Item 2006/07-191 Human Resources on the Consent Agenda.

The “REVISED EXHIBIT” added to Resolution 2006/07-191, Item C. “Interim/Superintendent/ President’s Employment Contract”, a new item, to the original resolution on the Consent Agenda.

The item did not reference the Interim/Superintendent/President’s name, length of contract, or salary level.

Blog:

The Brown Act (Section 54954.2) does not allow new items on the agenda unless they are emergency items (Section 54956.5) The “pink sheets” are for revisions of existing posted items, not new items. The Interim Superintendent’s contract was not posted on the original agenda resolution and was not an “emergency” item according to the definition in the Act.

How would the public know what items of business are to be considered by a government agency if an agency can place new items on an existing resolution after the posting of the agenda?

Conclusion and Outcome:
First, I had to request the resolution to be pulled from Consent and considered separately. Then, the Chair, denied my request to separate the added Item C. on the resolution for separate consideration.

I would now be required to vote against the original two items of the resolution (a Golden Handshake retirement and an administrative resignation), in order to vote against the newly added Item C. Interim/Superintendent/Presidents Employment Contract.

More hypocrisy and more Brown Act violations.

Public comment re/PE/”State audit faults college board”/June 15, 2007

Monday, June 18th, 2007

FYI

The news article written by Steve Fetbrandt, of the Press Enterprise concerning the recent California Teacher’s Retirement Final Audit Report, dated May 3, 2007, has the below public comment posted in response to the article and information.

“This is business as usual for the current board and interim president and former president. There are issues of conflict of interest by all, and they are able to execute their agendas with apparent impunity. Maybe this audit is the kink needed to weaken the MSJC leadership’s armour of corruption.”

“Kudos” to the anonymous author.

Academic Skills Courses Improve CC Students’ Success/Chronicle of Higher Education

Monday, June 18th, 2007

http://chronicle.com/daily/2007/06/2007061803n.htm?=attn

In a report posted in The Chronicle of Higher Education, “Community college students who take courses designed solely to improve their academic and planning skills are not only more likely to stay in college than other students, but five years later, are more likely to have earned a degree or transferred to a four-year institution.”

The report was completed at the Community College Research Center, at Columbia University’s Teachers College.

Blog:

MSJC offers such courses, however, I have not seen measurable data comparing MSJC degree completion rates and enrollment in these classes. The research position at MSJC has not been filled since 2006 when the former Dean of Research retired.

Decision making without correct data and analysis of data, often leads to incorrect assumptions and decisions which negatively impact the direction of the college. One of the major weaknesses of our college, as noted in the last accreditation report, is the lack of evidence and analysis in the Human Resource Department which negatively reflects upon the leadership of that department under Interim Superintendent Jon Tyler.

This has not been discussed by the board. It will be interesting to note how the college does address this issue for the October 2007 visit by the Accreditation team. I think it will be addressed in similar fashion as the CalSTRS issue……more administrative hypocrisy.

January 2006/PE article/”Trustee presses hiring dispute”

Saturday, June 16th, 2007

http://www.pe.com/localnews/inland/stories/PE_News_Local_H_saga28.22c4b0bf.html#

Here is another article from the past (January 2006) and here are additional district quotes pertaining to the Maas Companies contract with the MSJC college district and the re-hire of Interim Superintendent Richard Giese.

January 2006/Quotes

“Giese, who headed the college for six years, said he is frustrated by one trustee’s actions.”

“There’s no question that she’s intruded in my personal business.” Giese said.

“Jon Tyler, the college’s vice president of human resources, cautioned the board Thursday about the legalities of discussing Giese’s earnings.”

“Continuing inquiries is problematic to the board and could involve invasion of privacy.” Jon Tyler

“The college does not know exactly what Giese earns and if there are any doubts about retirement earnings, it should be between CalSTRS and Giese.” Gene Kadow

“A legal opinion will be sought by the February meeting.” Kadow

“The amount Giese earns from Maas and retirement is private. The board has tried to explain the situation, that the college has a contract with Maas, not Giese, several times before.” Gene Kadow

February 2006/PE article/”Board renews contract over member’s protest”

Saturday, June 16th, 2007

http://www.pe.com/localnews/hemet/stories/PE_News_Local_S_msjc10.111f798d.html#

The above Press Enterprise headlines from February 2006, concerned the Maas Companies re-hire contract of Richard Giese as Interim/Superintendent. It is interesting to note the tone of the comments in 2006 from 2007, posted in yesterdays Press Enterprise article by Steve Febrandt. They are quite different.

February 2006

“Her colleagues chastised her Thursday for continually trying to bring up a matter that they consider to be between Giese and CalSTRS, and not the college.”

“the college has no right to stop or reduce pay for services it is receiving.” Jon Tyler

June 2007

“Our efforts to report the income were impacted by conflicting legal arguments and the absence of a reporting mechanism or method through the Riverside County Office of Education.” Jon Tyler

“Everything was done in good faith and with a favorable opinion from the district’s legal counsel.” Gene Kadow

“It’s the college district’s responsibility - not mine - to report earnings to CalSTRS.” Michael Maas

“declined to comment on advice of his attorney.” Richard Giese
